verses.text: People told David, 'Look, the Philistines are attacking Keilah and are plundering the threshing floors.'
verses.comment: Keilah was a city in Judah (Josh. 15:44), significant as David continues to act as protector of God's people rather than merely hiding from Saul.

verses.text: So David inquired of the LORD, saying, 'Should I go and strike these Philistines?' The LORD answered David, 'Go, and strike the Philistines and save Keilah.'
verses.comment: David consults the Lord before acting, highlighting his reliance on God's guidance—a key spiritual lesson about discerning God's will in every decision (cf. James 1:5).

verses.text: But David's men said to him, 'Look, we're afraid here in Judah; how much more if we go to Keilah against the Philistine forces!'
verses.comment: David's followers express natural human fear, contrasting with their leader's faith—a recurring theme in Scripture, where leadership depends on trust in divine providence.

verses.text: Then David inquired again of the LORD. And the LORD answered him, 'Arise, go down to Keilah, for I will give the Philistines into your hand.'
verses.comment: Repetition of David's inquiry shows a healthy humility and spiritual discipline. The Lord reassures David of victory by His own hand, foreshadowing broader themes of God's sovereignty.

verses.text: So David and his men went to Keilah, fought the Philistines, led away their livestock, and struck them with great defeat. Thus David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.
verses.comment: David acts as a deliverer to Keilah, prefiguring the ultimate Deliverer—Jesus Christ, who rescues His people from spiritual bondage (cf. Luke 4:18-19).

verses.text: When Abiathar son of Ahimelech escaped to David at Keilah, he brought an ephod with him.
verses.comment: Abiathar the priest brings the ephod—used for seeking divine guidance—suggesting the importance of ordained leadership and ritual in discerning God's will.

verses.text: Saul was told that David had gone to Keilah, so Saul said, 'God has delivered him into my hand, for he has shut himself in by entering a town with gates and bars.'
verses.comment: Saul assumes God's favor, but his error underscores the difference between true and false discernment—only genuine obedience ensures divine blessing.

verses.text: So Saul summoned all the people for war, to go down to Keilah to besiege David and his men.
verses.comment: Saul misuses the resources of Israel, highlighting leadership gone astray in pursuit of personal power.

verses.text: When David learned that Saul was plotting evil against him, he said to Abiathar the priest, 'Bring the ephod here.'
verses.comment: David relies on priestly intercession and sacred objects for guidance, revealing the spiritual necessity of divinely-appointed mediation.

verses.text: Then David said, 'O LORD, God of Israel, your servant has surely heard that Saul intends to come to Keilah to destroy the city because of me.'
verses.comment: David's prayer is humble and honest, addressing the Lord as the protector of Israel. The plea invokes the safety of the community over personal interest, displaying selflessness.

verses.text: 'Will the men of Keilah surrender me into his hand? Will Saul come down, as your servant has heard? O LORD, God of Israel, please tell your servant.' The LORD said, 'He will come down.'
verses.comment: David seeks clear answers, and the Lord responds directly—an early example that God honors persistent, sincere prayer.

verses.text: Then David said, 'Will the men of Keilah surrender me and my men into the hand of Saul?' The LORD answered, 'They will surrender you.'
verses.comment: The betrayal by Keilah foreshadows later betrayals—including among Jesus' own followers (cf. John 13:18), a spiritual reminder that earthly alliances can falter, but God's faithfulness stands.

verses.text: So David and his men, about six hundred, left Keilah and went wherever they could. When Saul was told that David had escaped Keilah, he gave up his expedition.
verses.comment: David's escape and the loyalty of his men prefigure the Church's resilience under persecution.

verses.text: David stayed in the wilderness strongholds and remained in the hill country of the wilderness of Ziph. Saul searched for him continually, but God did not deliver David into his hand.
verses.comment: God's protection of David illustrates that divine providence is active even when threats seem overwhelming.

verses.text: David saw that Saul had come out to seek his life. David was in the wilderness of Ziph at Horesh.
verses.comment: The stark reality for David shows the intensity of opposition faced by those chosen for divine purposes.

verses.text: Then Jonathan, Saul's son, arose and went to David at Horesh, and strengthened his hand in God.
verses.comment: Jonathan's encouragement is a model of spiritual friendship. It hints at self-sacrifice and loyalty beyond family ties, reflecting the love described by Jesus (John 15:13).

verses.text: 'Do not fear,' Jonathan said to him, 'My father Saul will not find you. You shall be king over Israel, and I will be next to you. My father Saul knows this as well.'
verses.comment: Jonathan acknowledges David's future kingship, demonstrating submission to God's anointed—a spiritual lesson in true humility towards rightful authority.

verses.text: The two of them made a covenant before the LORD. Then David remained at Horesh, and Jonathan went home.
verses.comment: Their covenant highlights the sacredness of committed relationships before God—a reminder that true unity is founded in divine witness.

verses.text: Then the Ziphites came up to Saul at Gibeah, saying, 'Is David not hiding among us in the strongholds at Horesh, on the hill of Hachilah, south of Jeshimon?'
verses.comment: The betrayal by the Ziphites is a repetition of Keilah's betrayal, underscoring the recurring motif of human faithlessness versus divine faithfulness.

verses.text: 'Now, O king, come down according to all your heart's desire to come down, and our part shall be to surrender him into the king's hand.'
verses.comment: The Ziphites seek favor through betrayal, contrasting with Jonathan's loyalty and foreshadowing worldly alliances against divinely-chosen leaders.

verses.text: Saul said, 'Blessed are you by the LORD, for you have had compassion on me.'
verses.comment: Saul's words distort true blessing, seeking God's favor for unrighteous pursuit—a warning against invoking God's name for unjust causes.

verses.text: 'Go now, make more sure. Know and see the place where his foot is, and who has seen him there. For it is told me that he is very cunning.'
verses.comment: Saul's search strategy illustrates the fearful cunning with which worldly rulers pursue self-preservation.

verses.text: 'See therefore and take note of all the hiding places where he hides, and come back to me with sure information, and I will go with you. If he is in the land, I will search him out among all the thousands of Judah.'
verses.comment: Saul's relentless search underscores the persistence of opposition to God's chosen, but ultimately such opposition cannot overturn divine election.

verses.text: So they set out and went to Ziph before Saul. David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the Arabah south of Jeshimon.
verses.comment: A geographical shift highlights David's constant movement, emphasizing the pilgrim nature of God's people until final rest is found.

verses.text: Saul and his men went to seek him. David was told, so he went down to the rock and stayed in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard, he pursued David into the wilderness of Maon.
verses.comment: David seeks refuge in 'the rock'—echoing the biblical motif of God as the Rock, the ultimate refuge for His people (cf. Ps 18:2; 1 Cor 10:4).

verses.text: Saul went on one side of the mountain, and David and his men on the other. David was hurrying to get away from Saul, as Saul and his men were closing in on David and his men to capture them.
verses.comment: This close pursuit highlights God's sustained protection even in moments of apparent desperation.

verses.text: But a messenger came to Saul, saying, 'Hurry and come, for the Philistines have made a raid against the land.'
verses.comment: God uses external circumstances to deliver David, reminding us that divine providence works through history’s events.

verses.text: So Saul ceased pursuing David and went to meet the Philistines. That is why that place is called the Rock of Escape.
verses.comment: The 'Rock of Escape' stands as a memorial of God’s deliverance, pointing toward Christ the Rock, in whom we find true safety and redemption.

verses.text: David went up from there and lived in the strongholds of Engedi.
verses.comment: David’s refuge in Engedi prepares for the next episode in Saul’s pursuit. The theme of perseverance and trust resonates deeply in spiritual life—waiting for the fullness of God’s promise to manifest.
